title: 104_s1208
content: The "Family Fairness Act" is the short title of the Act. It amends the 1986 Code, specifically providing an additional earned income credit for married individuals. The "Family Fairness Act" amends the 1986 Code to provide an additional earned income credit for married individuals. The amendment allows for a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year based on earned income percentages and amounts. The "Family Fairness Act" introduces a new earned income credit for eligible married individuals based on income thresholds. Married individuals must have earned income exceeding $8,500 to qualify for the credit, which is reduced by 10 percentage points for each $1,000 over $16,000. Section 32(a)(2) is amended to replace "paragraph (1)" with "paragraph (1)(A)." Section 32(j) is amended regarding inflation adjustments for taxable years after a specific calendar year. Dollar amounts in paragraph (2)(B) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. In section 32, dollar amounts in paragraph (2)(B) will be adjusted for inflation based on the applicable calendar year, with different years for different dollar amounts. The amendments made by this section will adjust dollar amounts in subsections (b)(3) and (c)(4)(B) for inflation, rounding to the nearest multiple of $10 if necessary. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 3. EARNED INCOME CREDIT DENIED TO INDIVIDUALS NOT AUTHORIZED TO BE EMPLOYED IN THE UNITED STATES. The text discusses an amendment to the earned income tax credit eligibility requirements, stating that individuals must include their taxpayer identification numbers on their tax return to qualify. Additionally, if married, the spouse's taxpayer identification number must also be included. The amendment requires individuals to provide their taxpayer identification numbers, including their spouse's, on their tax return to qualify for the earned income tax credit. The amendment mandates the inclusion of taxpayer identification numbers on tax returns to qualify for certain tax credits. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 1995. SEC. 4 repeals the earned income credit for individuals without children, defining an eligible individual as someone with a qualifying child. It also amends tables to remove items for those with no qualifying children. Effective for taxable years after December 31, 1995. SEC. 5 introduces rules denying the earned income credit based on disqualified income. The amendment defines disqualified income to include capital gain net income, excess passive activity income over losses, and amounts includible in gross income under sections 652 or 662 for the taxable year. The amendment decreases the amount of disqualified income allowed for the taxable year. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. SEC. 6. Modification of adjusted gross income definition for earned income credit. The definition of adjusted gross income for the earned income credit is modified to include social security benefits and amounts received from a spouse under a divorce or separation instrument. The text discusses the tax treatment of child support payments, including provisions for support of children, exempt interest, and amounts received from qualified retirement plans. Additionally, a study will be conducted on the Federal tax treatment of child support payments. The Secretary will conduct a study on the Federal tax treatment of child support payments and report findings to the Senate and House committees. Recommendations may be provided to encourage parental responsibility for a child's economic well-being. The amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 7. EARNED INCOME CREDIT NOT ALLOWED UNTIL RECEIPT OF EMPLOYER'S WITHHOLDING STATEMENT. The new paragraph added to Section 6401(b) specifies that the earned income credit must be verified by comparing it with information from employee tax returns or self-employment tax returns. This rule also applies to advanced payments of the earned income credit. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on potential delays in processing tax returns due to this amendment and report findings to relevant committees within a year. SEC. 8. Prevention of fraud in electronic returns requires new applicants to provide fingerprints and credit information. Existing electronic return originators must also comply with these requirements.
